Award.AwardTitle: CBET-EPSRC: Enhancing the CSMHyK fluid dynamics calculations via the inclusion of a stochastic model of hydrate nucleation, agglomeration and growth

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The abundance of natural gas hydrate deposits across the world could provide abundant energy resources for the future. Natural gas hydrates are solid structures formed by water and gas that can block oil & gas pipelines, which can lead to pipeline ruptures, causing spills and environmental disasters, production interruptions, and even loss of life. The ability to predict gas hydrate formation and fluid dynamics based on molecular-level models has the potential to revolutionize the strategies used for gas hydrate control in oil and gas pipelines, as well as other gas hydrate energy applications. The predictive capability of gas hydrate fluid dynamics models is currently lacking due to the inability to fundamentally model the timescales for hydrate formation. The principle aim of the project is to develop a kinetic molecular model to predict gas hydrate formation times based on a synergistic experimental and molecular modeling campaign, leading to the ability to predict quantitatively gas hydrate formation in pipelines. The project is also focused on inclusion of under-represented minority students in STEM disciplines, via outreach activities that target students at all stages of development, industry engagement, and state-of-the-art web-based materials.

The goal of the project is to quantify the rate-limiting mechanisms in gas hydrate formation to provide a predictive fluid dynamics model for gas hydrate formation. Identification of which mechanisms of hydrate formation (i.e. nucleation, growth, agglomeration, adhesion) is rate-limiting under different scenarios remains unknown, and yet must be overcome in order to have a predictive fluid dynamics model. This knowledge gap will be filled by the four main aims of the project: (1) obtain free energy barriers representative of gas hydrate growth, agglomeration and adhesion; (2) assess the reliability of (1) with in-situ micromechanical force and film growth measurements; (3) develop a computationally efficient stochastic kinetic Monte Carlo model that incorporates information from (1) and (2); (4) incorporate the outcomes from (3) into the transient fluid dynamics model and validate this predictive stochastic model against flow-loop experiments. This approach will provide a potential game-changing improvement to the fluid dynamics simulation model and molecular-based predictions of hydrate formation in pipelines. This research was funded under the NSF Engineering – UKRI Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council opportunity NSF 20-510.” Co-PIs included Alberto Striolo and Michail Stamatakis at the University College of London.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Clathrate hydrates are crystalline inclusion compounds formed by water and gas at elevated pressures and low temperatures. The abundance of natural gas hydrate deposits across the world could provide significant energy resources for the future, as well as long-term CO2 storage. Gas hydrates can form in oil & gas pipelines, which can lead to severe safety and environmental hazards. The overall goal of this project was to investigate the rate-limiting mechanisms (for different system conditions) previously unknown in hydrate plug formation, in order to advance the fluid dynamics models by development of a molecular-based kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) model with state-of-the-art experimental validation. The project outcomes address the critical fundamental knowledge gaps for hydrate growth and agglomeration by coupling molecular kinetic modeling with in-situ interfacial and kinetic experiments.

Specifically, the major project outcomes include: (1) Established that hydrate surface wettability and hydrate film growth play a central role in hydrate inter-particle agglomeration via capillary bridging. Through the unique closely coupled systematic in-situ interfacial experiments and molecular dynamics simulations we show that the hydrate formation process and resulting hydrate morphology (atomically smooth versus rough surfaces) strongly affect surface wettability. These findings provide new insight into the hydrate adhesion mechanism and advanced understanding of the hydrate growth process. (2) Established that reduced hydrate surface wettability and film growth rate are key parameters to natural surfactants (in higher asphaltene contents of "non-plugging oils"), modelled by polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) exhibiting "non-plugging behavior. Complementary molecular dynamics simulations reveal a direct correlation between hydrate surface wetting properties and binding free energy, and entropy changes upon solvation at the solvent-hydrate interfaces. (3) Established that ultra-low concentrations of a model kinetic inhibitor, polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), reduces interparticle force, film growth rate, and particle sintering; surface adsorbed PVP molecules induce major morphology changes even at low concentrations. Hence, demonstrating a new control functionality for KHIs. (4) First direct experimental structure-adhesion relations for hydrate particle-particle interaction (adhesion) forces from in-situ high pressure micromechanical force measurements on defined-molecule anti-agglomerant molecules. (5) Discovered new mechanistic control of micelle concentration on hydrate growth kinetics. Determined the presence of sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) can be synergistic or antagonistic, depending on the system conditions. In the latter case, SDS detrimentally affects CO2 hdyrate growth, and in the presence of tetrohydrofuran (THF) may shift the critical micelle concentration (CMC) of SDS downwards, allowing micelle formation in systems with nominal concentrations of SDS below the CMS. (6) Elucidated the key molecular mechanistic control of kinetic additives, polyvinylcaprolactam (PVCap, a kinetic inhibitor) and SDS (a kinetic promoter) on hydrate growth. Methane transport across the oil-water interface, and hence methane solubility in the aqueous phase is found to be strongly correlated with hydrate crystal growth kinetics. 

Collectively, the new mechanistic and kinetic insights determined in (1)-(6) above using state-of-the-art interfacial and growth rate experiments and molecular dynamics simulations are incorporated into the development of a compuationally efficient and reliable KMC engine. The outcomes of this project help to resolve long standing questions on hydrate particle interactions, and reveal new insight into the role hydrate interfacial interactions play in the key rate-limiting mechanisms controlling hydrate formation kinetics and agglomeration. The combination of in-situ experiments and molecular computational approaches, including molecular dynamics simulations and a molecular-based kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) model, identify the controlling mechanisms that are required to enhance fluid-dynamics models. These project outcomes can contribute towards ensuring safe and environmentally sound strategies for hydrate pipeline plugging mitigation, as well as greenhouse gas capture and storage using a hydrate-based technology.

The PI and graduate students developed during the project hands-on activities focused on interfacial properties and applications and presented these at the Rocky Mountain Camp for Dyslexic Children in Colorado. SWEET summer workshops for middle and high school teachers with activities related to the energy transition and utilization was organized/hosted by the PI (during and after the COVID pandemic), involving scientists from the Colorado School of Mines, National Renewable Energy Lab, and STEM middle and high school teachers, including schools with a significant underrepresented population.
